The Ancient Mysteries of the Perilous Japanese Strait are to
be Studied.
The furious torrents and whirlpools making things rough for
ships in Japan’s Narute Strait are about to be studied in
a daring expedition. Two hundred Japanese experts will work
on the project. This area, between the island of Shikoku
and the Islet of Awaji, off Kobe, is known as a "nightmare”
to sailors. For 3 days the expedition will attempt to
learn enough to expose the mysteries of the Strait, dramatized
for centuries in Japanese myth and legend. The Narute
Strait, incidentally, has become a must for tourists both
from Japan and abroad.

I have as my guest today Tokugen Yamamoto. He's going to
tell us something about Soba and Udon--the popular Japanese
food In Tokyo alone over a million and a half dishes are
sold per day] Well, tell us more about "Soba".
Soba traces its origin back to the time of the Emperor
Gensho (8th Century). It was introduced by a Chinese
Buddhist Priest. As an emergency food in times of famine
the value of soba was realized early.
Let's see: Soba is a kind of buckwheat noodle; and udon
corresponds roughly to a flour noodle, something like thick
macaroni. In Italy they'd both be forms of pasta.
That's right. Since soba flour is not suitable for cooking
in the manner of Italian macaroni, a Korean priest many
years ago tried mixing SOBA flour with wheat flour. Since
then various improvements in cooking have been brought
about, as a result of which SOBA became an indispensable
food for the Japanese,
